article.headline: Washington 88, Columbia 51
article.story: SEATTLE (AP) -- The Washington Huskies want their upcoming Pac-10 opponents to know they're a different team than the one that missed the league tournament last season. Bobby Jones scored 18 points, all in the first half, and Tre Simmons added 15, leading the Huskies to an 88-51 victory over Columbia on Tuesday night. Washington will open its Pac-10 season in the Bay Area this week. The Huskies are at California on Friday and at Stanford on Sunday. "This was a great motivation going into the conference," said Jones, a 6-foot-6 sophomore forward. "We have good momentum now." The Huskies (5-3), facing the Ivy League Lions from New York for the first time since 1949, got 13 points from Brandon Roy and 11 from Curtis Allen. Hakeem Rollins had nine rebounds for Washington, which outrebounded Columbia 37-28. Washington beat San Diego State on Sunday to end a three-game losing streak. "We've just been trying to build," Rollins said. "I thought the team's overall performance was excellent tonight." The Huskies were so sure they could beat Columbia that they decided to keep 6-9 sophomore center Anthony Washington out of the game. Washington underwent foot surgery last spring. "We'll see," second-year Huskies coach Lorenzo Romar said when asked how his team would do in the Pac-10 this season after being 5-13 in the conference last season. "It's like raising your kids. You're not sure how good a job you've done until they've left the house." Dodson Worthington led Columbia with 12 points. The Huskies were ahead 58-21 at halftime, with Jones leading the way on 6-for-8 shooting and Allen scoring 11 on 3-for-6. The 58 points was the most in a half by Washington since it had 59 the first half against Portland State on Nov. 28, 2000. Roy hit a 14-footer from the wing and Will Conroy made a 3-pointer in the first 2:10 before Worthington sank two free throws with 3:13 gone. Then the Huskies outscored the Lions 19-2 to take a 21-4 lead with 6:42 gone. Jones shot 0-for-6 in the second half. His career high is 19 points. "I was amazed at my first half, man," Jones said. "If I had done in the second half what I did in the first half, that would have been awesome." Columbia (3-7) didn't get its first basket and first official shot until 4:38 was gone when Dragutin Kravic made a layup. The Lions shot 6-for-23 in the opening half. The closest Columbia got in the second half was 60-27 after a layup by Matt Preston with 3:39 gone. First-year coach Joe Jones, who got the Columbia job after six seasons as an assistant at Villanova, inherited a program that went 2-25, including 0-14 in the Ivy League, last season. Jones said he was disappointed about the way the Lions played in the first half. "I think Columbia basketball is playing hard," he said. "I thought Washington outtoughed us in the first half."
